Combined loss reduction to residences and commercial property.
Instantaneous production *reduction* of 8 percent after the shock. ARIO model application to Hurricane Katrina landfall in Louisiana. Katrina made landfall in August 2005.
Louisiana, last four months of 2005, production loss underestimates the observed growth loss of close to 4.5% due to model limitations.
Sum of production losses (positive and negative) over the entire reconstruction period.
Decrease in housing services because of damaged houses and buildings.
Total production loss plus the part of production that has to be dedicated to reconstruction instead of normal consumption.
Ratio of total losses to direct losses.
EAR of 1.44 for $100b direct losses. Indirect losses are total losses minus direct losses. The value is negative as it is the *additional* loss caused by the disaster.
For a disaster with $100 billion direct losses.
For a disaster with $200 billion direct losses, total losses are twice as large as direct costs.
Total losses in modified climate scenario compared to present climate scenario. The year 2009 is used since the study was published in 2009.
Total losses in modified climate scenario compared to present climate scenario. The year 2009 is used since the study was published in 2009.
A 10-percent increase in potential intensity translates into a 59 percent increase in total economic losses. The year 2009 is used since the study was published in 2009.
Likelihood of a hurricane causing more than $50 billion in damages doubles with a 10-percent increase in potential intensity. The year 2009 is used since the study was published in 2009.
Reconstruction costs increased up to 40 percent in some regions of Florida after the 2004 hurricane season due to shortages of roofers.
